segments.text: General, Brigadier General Johnson, today is July 14, 1981.
Let's start about, start talking about your upbringing.
Can you tell us where, where and when you were born?
Yeah, I was born in Houston, Texas, May the 2nd, 1921.
Okay, can you tell me about your parents, their occupations or backgrounds?
Well, my dad, uh,
At the time that I was born, I was working for the city of Houston as a health officer.
However, he had been a machinist in the Southern Pacific Roundhouse in Houston.
At the time, one of Houston's most popular
Mayor Oscar Holcomb ran for office the first time, and dad helped carry the roundhouse, which was a considerable vote.
And as such, the mayor carried him over to the city, and dad worked for the city off and on while Holcomb was mayor and under a couple of other mayors.
My mother is a pretty well-educated lady, and though she was principally a housewife and mother, she did substitute school teaching.
I have one brother.
He's four years younger than I, and he too is a graduate of Texas A&M.
What type of education did your father have?
My father had only a high school education.
He was a enlisted man in World War I.
Got all the way to the rank of corporal.
We lived in a middle class neighborhood.
I went to private school through the
second or third grade and then entered public school.
As such, I guess it was a year ahead of in school of most children my age.
So much so that I was 16 years old in May and I entered A&M.
At 16?
At 16, yes.
Which incidentally, I was the second youngest in our class.
Come to bear later on.
Did your mother go to college?
She went to college, but did not graduate.
Do you remember where she went?
No, I don't.
Coincidentally, she and I went to the same high school in Houston, Texas.
Same building, same location.
What type of student were you in high school?
In high school, I was probably a good student.
Nowhere making all A's or anything like that.
Strong enough that
The only courses that gave me any trouble were Spanish.
At that time, Spanish was a two-year requirement.
I remember having to repeat one semester of Spanish.
I had strength enough to be company commander of a junior ROTC unit at the high school.
We had three companies, so we had our own battalion.
I was one of the three company commanders.
So you became involved in the military early then in life.
Yes, yes.
I knew from real early in life that the two things that I was interested in doing, that was building and being in the military.
Why did you know that?
How could you tell?
Well, as...
Looking back, we had an ideal, what you might call, miniature battlefield between our garage and the garage next door to us.
Incidentally, I was born in my house that I lived in, not in a hospital.
We had just a large space.
We were constantly using miniature soldiers and tanks and things like that and playing war games.
And I was always the one that was doing the building and the excavation and laying supposedly the mine fields and things like that.
And that's just not something that we do every now and then.
all but just a constant game.
And when the day was over, we would quietly leave everything where it was and just take a little break.
And this was one of our favorite pastimes as we were growing up.
I was always stringing off things, getting things ready in our own imagination to be built and things like that.

I didn't call it an argument or a flash or anything like that with my father because he had grandiose ideas that I was going to be a patrol engineer and I knew damn good I was going to be a civil engineer.
Sooner or later, I guess I won out, but it cost maybe a couple of years of career or something like that, having to do the things that he wanted me to do.
Was he ever involved in the military?
Oh, you said he was during the World War.
Just during the World War.
But did he remain in the reserves or anything like that?
No.
So he didn't come from a military background, yet you knew at an early age that you wanted to be in the military.
How can you explain that?
I don't know, because I even had employment to West Point and couldn't pass physical for West Point, so...
I chose other routes of getting to where I got.
There was a program.
It's called the Citizens Military Training Camps.
I don't know whether you've ever been exposed to them or not, but which right here in San Antonio in Camp Bullitt.
out north of town here.
It's one of the locations that young men from all over this part of the country would come each summer and train and study.
And it was a four-year process called the basic red, white, and blue.
And after the four years and the completion of what was known as the 10 series course,
by correspondence, he would then be commissioned as second lieutenant.

The three years of ROTC in high school could be substituted for the basic, and I finished the red course and the white course and was prepared to go back to the blue, but I attained a contract for advanced military training at A&M
There was no requirement to go back to next year, but I could go back any time, so I kind of figured I'll take the contract through Senior ROTC and head the commission that way.
But I made up my mind I was going to be a commission officer.
outstanding Captain of the Artillery Commandant when I was in high school that took a personal interest in his cadet officers.
What was his name?
His name was Paul Van Tuyl, V-A-N-T-U-Y-L.
He was a second father to each of the cadet officers, and we could turn to him for counseling, anything, anything about life that we wanted to talk about.
I'm sure that he had an effect.
Let's get back to your parents for a minute.
What type of...

character with your father and your mother my father and mother are still living and he is a character my father was the first born generation of danish stock the johnson comes from denmark my grandfather came from denmark when he was 17 years old
Where and how he met my grandmother, I don't know.
Who was Otis, O-T-I-S?
She was a third generation away from James Otis, the revolutionary writer.
No kidding.
Yes.
That's where the O comes from, Otis in my name.
They came down after he entered the country in New England.
They came down to East Texas, and Grandpa went into the lumber business.
My dad had three brothers and one sister.
They lived in the Groveton Huntsville area and did lumber over there in the Piney Woods.
He, I don't guess he and I are too much different, because there is truth in the saying, a part head gains, because when he gets pretty well set in his ways, he's kind of difficult.
He has done all that he could with
Everything that he had to work with to raise the family and provide us with a good life.
So he was a hard working guy?
Oh yes, very.
The fact is, even to this day, he's now a hybridizer of Hemerichalis.
That's a daylily hybridizer.
He actually breeds them, names them.
grows them professionally, and works the garden himself.
Not in the best of physical conditions, but that's his life.
When he gets into something, he's into it all the way.
Looking back, we all know that Jerry made mistakes.
He made two races, two attempts.
to become state railroad commissioner.
At the time, my brother and I were young.
There was no way that we could, and probably didn't even realize it at the time, but looking back, he didn't have the qualifications to become state railroad commissioner.
But he thought he did, and it cost a hell of a lot of money to become state commissioner.
And that probably set us back financially,
My brother's living comfortably, and my mother and father are living comfortably.
I guess we've made it through.
I want to stop here.
Okay, now can you sort of characterize your mother?
Yeah, my mother, I'd have to say, is the
is really the strength in the center of the family.
She's the one that has probably done more for both my brother and me, has been the point around which the family grew up.
whenever there were real problems.
Really, I guess Mother was the one that seemed to pull everything together.
And my mother, well, I can't say that she alone.
Both of them were quite active in Parent Teachers Association, both at my school and my brother's school.
But in spite of the fact that we had no sisters, my mother became the volunteer head of the Girl Scouts in the Houston area.
She was the top volunteer woman.
She great in service, social work, and I'm sure that
I picked that up from her rather than from my father.
My father was a hard worker and a man always trying to make money.
I don't mean greedy or selfish, but that was his, realizing his shortcomings, he was going to make it one way or the other.
And again, as they both are growing old there, she's the
She's the mainstay of the two of them.
Who is the authority in the household now?
Well, I don't think there is one right now.
I'd say Mother was.
Dad often thought he was, but I think Mother had trouble with him.
Was religion an important influence?
It was to a degree, and it's interesting that you bring it up because
I don't know how well you know Houston, but there's some things that I don't know to precise dates and things like that.
Their acquaintances and courtships took place
in Bell County, which is in a little community called Holland.
And I don't know what happened or how it moved from Holland to the Houston Heights, which is out on Heights Boulevard, Washington Avenue, out in that area.
And yet, when I was born and
We grew up, we lived all the way across town on the east side, out in Eastwood.
But every Sunday, we'd go back to the Presbyterian Church out in the Heights.
Well, this took place until, oh, about the time, I guess, I was in the
fifth, sixth, or seventh grade, something like that.
And all of the friends that I had there in our neighborhood were going to an Episcopal church that was just about two blocks from where we lived.
And I guess I was the first one to balk.
And I said, well, you all go on to the Heights, but I'm going to go over here where all of my friends are going to Sunday school and church.
And didn't seem to have any problem.
I was permitted to do it.
And I was confirmed in the Episcopal Church.
As a result of my going, my brother became confirmed in the Episcopal Church.
My mother then switched over to the Episcopal Church.
From what?
From Presbyterian.
Where they were all going out on a hike.
And later my father did.
My wife, when I married her, was Methodist.
She's now Episcopal.
My brother's first wife went to the Episcopal Church.
I mean, joined the Episcopal Church.
And so we just made a swing from the Presbyterian to the Episcopal Church.
And yes,
It played a great deal.
I was, as I grew up, I was about, you have to compare me to a matchstick, all the way through school, even when I came out of A&M.
When I came out of A&M, I was six foot two and a half.
I weighed 139 pounds.
And I was that way all the way through school.
Well, in junior high school, I could play basketball.
But when I reached high school, I was out of my league.
But we had a preacher at this Episcopal church that made up his mind that he was going to draw the young people to the church.
And he had all types of programs.
And one of the programs was a sports program.
We had basketball teams, and we had tackle football teams, and we had complete full uniforms and so on.
The fact is, the worst football game that I ever played, playing for that church, and we were known as the Eastwood Green, was against the University of Houston.
The church played the University of Houston.
Now this was back when the University of Houston was a junior college in downtown Houston up on the second or third floor of a building before it became what it is now.
But again, lightweight as I was, that guy on the other side was about 185 pounds.
And it took two of us to move him every once in a while.
But yes, both because of this...
Gordon Reese was the preacher's name.
Reverend Reese's interest in the youth and the programs that he had to attract us to the church, it was quite important.
I have later in life, they come out,
I served as a vesterman on the Bishop's Committee, what the Episcopal Church calls the committee that runs a mission that's not yet a full church.
I've been a lay reader.
It means an awful lot.
I am a member of the Episcopal Church here in Winthrop.
My dad and mother are still members.
I don't know whether my brother is or not.
You've had a successful career.
In what way would you credit your parents for that?
Well, I don't know.
limited it to words.
My father, as Bud and I were growing up, insisted that we realize that every man, and I use that collectively for Van Allen, every man is good.
until the first time he does wrong.
And then if he does you wrong the second time, that's your fault.
And you've got to accept people on that basis.
Everybody's good.
The second time, it's your fault.
And my mother taught us way back in the beginning
If you ever decide that you're going to steal, steal real, real big.
Don't steal little.
Steal big.
And I think that hit both my butt and me, and just, you know, every time temptation might come your way, you think, hey, I didn't think about it.
And she explained it, but that was what she was trying to do.
And my brother had had a very successful life.
He had been assistant high school principal in Houston.
In fact, he was assistant principal of the first high school that was integrated in Houston.
He, too, is an Air Force.
Reserve, retired colonel.
He's waiting for aid before he can start growing benefits.
He retired as a retired colonel.
But he's a farmer for Potato Shrine in Houston, which is a very big job in the Messiah Corps.
The associations that I've had with my parents, of course, began to be limited after I was 16 and went off to school.
Because I was in that baby class at 41.
And though I was only 20 years old, they commissioned me, and pow, we were gone.
And I did come back and got out of the service.
I had five or six years.
close association because we both lived in Houston and then piled back in the service and gone again.
So I guess really anything that I received or from them came about in the first 16 years of life.
What kind of a student were you in high school?
In high school?
You said you were an average student, but were you better in the engineering or the math courses?
Were those your favorite subjects?
Well, in high school, math was my favorite subject.
Physics.
Any time that a course was based on pure memory, I'd have problems.
I just found it very, very difficult to put courses to memory.
Jumping even at college, for instance, I took the two semesters of freshman chemistry, five semesters before I managed to get by.
Because I could find no way to take chemistry back to reading or math.
I mean, it was either a memory course or it wasn't.
Again, we're way out, way ahead.
But when I pursued my master's degree and had to take a course in geology, I was back to a memory course.
There was no way to take mathematics and tie it to any type of reasoning.
It was just a plain old memory course.
There I was at that time.
I was a major.
I think I managed to make a C out of Jolly.
Were you interested in a number of organizations or any organizations during those years in high school?
Yeah, I'd always, I've been since, well, back
my age, you couldn't go into the Boy Scouts until 12 years old, and we didn't have such a thing as a cup.
And I went into the Boy Scouts and got to be a Star Scout, I guess, before going off to college.
But the managed to
Stay busy and stay out of trouble by the program that they had at the church, the Boy Scout program.
I sold papers on Saturday night.
I didn't have a regular paper route.
It's something that's not done anymore in the community.
The Houston Post and the Houston Chronicle both were coming out on Sunday night.
I mean, Saturday night.
It's a Sunday paper.
And we'd pedal the bikes up and down the streets and call in the paper and sell them.
Then on Sunday mornings, I threw two freebie routes that I had to ride about six or eight miles from home to even start those routes.
I mean, they were that far.
No other particular organization.
I didn't belong to the highway.
I didn't belong to the Y.
Did you consider yourself popular or well-liked in high school?
Yes, I think so.
Probably more so in high school than in elementary school.
Where I went to school, we had the first five grades in elementary, and then six, seven, eight in junior high school, and then nine, ten, eleven in high school.
And in the eighth grade, I started going with a girl, and we went with each other all the way through high school.

end of my freshman year in college before we ever broke up and we were always in a small group of people but that small group would in turn be in larger groups but we had pretty much our own small group the fact is in high school there were four of us that called ourselves the 4-h's
Harold, Hub, Morris, and then we had to really reach for the other one, and we reached for his last name, and it was Haberly.
All four of us ended up going into the military.
Harold Lewis is deceased now.
He was in the Army.
Haberly.
Retired as a full colonel in the Marines and is living in the Washington area.
I don't know where Horace is.
Probably somewhere around Huntsville or a girl from East Texas, something like that.
But we were just constantly together, all four of us.

were in junior rotc and three of us were cadet captains and that just pretty much made our little group you know but uh we weren't ostracized i don't guess we ever really stopped to think are we well like you know
What about leadership?
I'm always interested when I talk to generals about developing, when did leadership develop?
About what age?
Some people, it starts very early.
They start taking sort of leadership roles in school or at A&M.
And then other people, it's not until they're in their 20s.
When did you think you started to become a leader?
Well, let's see.

Looking back, I'd have to probably say that somewhere in the 10th grade, because it was then that they started narrowing down to determine who were going to be the company commanders the year following in high school.
Though I'm always one to immediately,
and A&M as we'll get to somewhere down the line.
Drill field marketing and command to me is not necessarily leadership, but it's part, I mean, it's an outward sign or display of what a guy's willing to do.
But we hadn't
We had some things in our school that made it very difficult to be a company commander of ROTC.
First, we had no campus.
We were a masonry building built in a U-shape with an asphalt court in downtown Houston.
And in order to

perfect close order drill, we actually had to leave the block or the campus and go some eight or 10 blocks away into a neighborhood that was sparsely populated and then actually drill on the city streets where there was very little, no traffic.
And that was completely in the hands of the cadet company commander to get them out there and get them back on time and be sure he got them all back
And we were drilling with rifles, I mean, on the street.
And then each year, the various companies competed, even though we had three companies at Sam Houston.
All of the companies in the Houston area would compete in close-order competition at small diamonds.
Buffalo Stadium, which was a professional ball club in Houston, which was the best drill company in Houston, and so on.
A lot of
assistance is required of junior officers and non-commissioned officers.
Even in a situation like that, just coping with a problem of not being able to drill right, you know, get the rifles and go 100 yards outside and start drilling.
The old man was around.
Ventile was around every once in a while, but he wasn't standing over you the whole time to see that you did it right.
ready to bark at you if you did it wrong.
You have enough faith.
When did they start this program?
Do you remember?
This high school military program?
Oh, I don't know.
Of course, it's going on now, but I don't know when it started.
It had been going on, oh, I don't know, six or eight years before I was here.
So it was probably developed sometime in the 30s?
I wouldn't think so.
But I don't know.
And I think you'd only find it in the larger public schools because it was a financial burden that a small school system really couldn't maintain.
This particular captain also taught physics at our high school so that he had both the military and physics.
But then over the city, there was a full-time major, and he ultimately was promoted to lieutenant colonel.
He was on active duty.
He was an army officer.
And he had three or four sergeants that he had to work for him.
Because at the end of the year, we'd have to carry in all the arms out to certain locations so that they weren't stored in the high schools during the summer time.
They were all stored in an armory.
I don't know when it started.
Now, tell me about your attempt to get into West Point.
Was that your primary objective when you graduated from high school?
Well,
My primary objective was to become a commission officer.
The attempt to get into West Point was one made knowing good and well that I couldn't do it because when I was six years old, five or six years old, a neighbor boy
picked up a piece of asbestos roofing slate and sailed it across the yard and picked me up here.
And it knocked...
Right above the eye.
Yeah.
And it knocked the left lens over partially behind my nose.
And it reduced my sight to 2060.
Mm-hmm.
And... Actually, it's 2200 correctable to 2060.
And...
I knew that the chances of getting into West Point were slim.
But nevertheless, one of the Texas senators offered the appointment.
And I went to the doc and took the physical.
And of course, there's no way of doing it.
So OK, we're not going to do it at West Point.
We're going to do it some other way.
And physical restrictions and the reserve program have never been what they are to one of the academies.
I know because my older son couldn't pass the one to get in the Air Force Academy and he's now a regular Air Force Major.
Was your primary aim then to become an engineer then?
Had you made that decision?
Well, I'd have to say my primary aim was to become a commissioned officer.
My secondary was to become an engineer.
Okay, and that's why you decided to go to A&M?
That's right.
Okay, before we get to A&M, then, let's talk about the Great Depression.
In what way did that have an impact?
The what?
The Depression of the 1930s.
In what way did that have an impact on you or your family?
Oh.
I guess...
The impact that it had was, of course, at A&M.
I worked at something at A&M the whole time I was there.
For example?
Well, the head of the publicity department at Texas A&M
G. Byron Winstead.
Byron's mother lived three doors from our house where I was born and where I was reared.
And from the day I entered school, I worked in the publishing department, flipping, typing.
So I typed then with two fingers.
I now use two fingers and two thumbs, and I can probably get up to 60, 65 words a minute, something like that.
But that's the way many people learn to type and still type.
The fact is I was on, what do you call it, the team that helped make John Kimbrough All-American.

Because, sure, the guy makes it on the football field, but if he had got the publicity department behind him that's pushing the statistics and pushing the stories and everything else, you know, everything kind of falls in the cracks.
But that was a paying job.
Well, see, we're at A&M now, back up and forth.
My junior year, I was a...
Junior sports editor, which was the assistant sports editor.
It's a paying job, or it was on the battalion.
At that time, the battalion was three times a week.
I don't know what it is now.
Probably daily now.
We were three times a week.
My senior year, I was the sports editor.
My roommate and I had each had
a cleaning and pressing concession within our organization.
So any way that we could make a buck, we would make a buck.
The summer of either the summer of 40 or the summer of 39,
Another cadet who I give an awful lot of credit to, what I learned and where I went and what all I've done, by the name of E.C.G.
Boats, he was also in the sports racket like I was in.
O-A-T-S?
O-A-T-E-S, E.C.G.
Boats.
I'll look him up in the directory in there.
He and I washed every window on A&M campus, except the dormitories, inside and out.
Two people couldn't do that now.
But back in that day and time, but it took us half the summer to do it.
But that was our job.
We were employed to do it.
How much did you make, a quarter and a half?
Whatever the student wage was.
I'm thankful to have it because, you know, I doubt that it was probably not much more than that, you know.
I attended summer school a couple of summers.
During the summers, I worked as a table waiter.
I did not work as a table waiter during the record years because I couldn't do that and do the newspaper work also.
The newspaper work even took me away from the campus.
You were in California?
Oh, yeah.
When A&M played UCLA in 1940, I went out with a team.
That was out on the train.
As a sports editor?
Yeah.
I bet you that was a great experience.
Oh, it was terrific.
Was that the first time you ever left Texas?
Yeah, it probably was.
Dean E.J.
Kyle was the dean of agriculture and the head of athletics for A&M.
He was whatever that ruling committee is.
A fellow by the name of Angel was the
faculty advisor to the battalion, and Angel will come up later on in my military life.
And the two of them said, why shouldn't we take the sports editor with us?
Well, there we went.
That was quite a thing to go out, stay in the Hollywood Roosevelt, cover the game from the press box out there.
Just represent A&M, train come back.
What did you think?
What did you think of California?
Oh, I thought it was everything that everybody else did.
Fantastic.
We had a good one with Mary Martin.
Let's draw off the record on that.
Well, you can edit anything out if you want.
Kimbrough had shin splints.

And the coach was keeping him under rapid key, and I thought that was the last thing we wanted, was to let UCLA know that something was wrong with his legs, because that's the first thing they'd go for, you know, to try to get him out of the game.

Mary Barton, a good old Texas gal, well, they brought her up to the hotel to make some publicity shots and said, now, Mary, we're going to give you a thermometer, and we want you to take John's temperature.
And Mary says, what did I do?
Put it in his mouth?
John said, Mary, have you ever taken a cow temperature?
She said, no.
And he said, well, stick it in my mouth.
Stick it in my mouth.
He was just disgusted as hell.
No, back to the Depression.
Dad and Mom managed to keep the college bills paid.
And then it was up to me to make the rest of it.
Spending money, that was up to me.
What political persuasion was your father?
You said that he ran for office.
Democrat.
And what type of Democrat?
A liberal Democrat, moderate, or conservative?
Well, back in the old days, I don't know.
I wouldn't really say.
He has, since then...
He was one conservative Republican, and then he went back.
I happen to know that dad and mother both supported Carter when Carter was elected president.
I guess one of the reasons the Depression didn't really hurt us too much is this was one of the long stretches that my dad worked for the city.
so he wasn't having to use his card as a machinist to get a job and so on but uh even at that time i can remember many many meals when i was in high school many many meatless needs
